title: George Matheson
text:
George Matheson <a href="Fellow%20of%20the%20Royal%20Society%20of%20Edinburgh">FRSE</a> (27 March 1842 – 28 August 1906) was a Scottish <a href="Minister%20of%20the%20Church%20of%20Scotland">minister</a> and <a href="hymn%20writer">hymn writer</a> and prolific author. He was blind from the age of 17.
Life.
Born at 39 Abbotsford Place in <a href="Glasgow">Glasgow</a>, to George Matheson (d.1891), a merchant and Jane Matheson (a second cousin), he was the eldest of eight children.
At age 20, George Matheson was engaged to be married but began going blind. When he broke the news to his fiancee, she decided she could not go through life with a blind husband. 
He was educated at <a href="Glasgow%20Academy">Glasgow Academy</a> and the <a href="University%20of%20Glasgow">University of Glasgow</a>, where he graduated first in classics, <a href="logic">logic</a> and <a href="philosophy">philosophy</a>. In his twentieth year he became totally <a href="blindness">blind</a>, but he held to his resolve to enter the ministry, and gave himself to theological and historical study. In 1879 the <a href="University%20of%20Edinburgh">University of Edinburgh</a> conferred upon him the honorary degree of <a href="Doctor%20of%20Divinity">D.D.</a>. In 1890, he became a fellow of the <a href="Royal%20Society%20of%20Edinburgh">Royal Society of Edinburgh</a>, upon the proposal of <a href="Sir%20William%20Thomson">Sir William Thomson</a>, <a href="Robert%20Flint">Robert Flint</a>, <a href="Hugh%20Macmillan">Hugh Macmillan</a> and <a href="James%20Lindsay%20%28theologian%29">James Lindsay</a>.
He died suddenly of <a href="apoplexy">apoplexy</a> (stroke) at Avenell House in <a href="North%20Berwick">North Berwick</a> on 28 August 1906 in Edinburgh and is buried with his parents in the <a href="Glasgow%20Necropolis">Glasgow Necropolis</a>. The grave lies near the summit.
He never married.
Service.
He was licensed to preach by the Presbyrery of Glasgow in 1866 and started as an assistant minister of <a href="Sandyford">Sandyford</a>. His first ministry began in 1868 at <a href="Innellan">Innellan</a>, on the <a href="Argyll">Argyll</a> coast between <a href="Dunoon">Dunoon</a> and <a href="Toward">Toward</a>. He stayed 18 years. His books on "Aids to the Study of German Theology, Can the Old Faith live with the New?, The Growth of the Spirit of Christianity from the First Century to the Dawn of the Lutheran Era", established his reputation as a liberal and spiritually minded theologian; and <a href="Victoria%20of%20the%20United%20Kingdom">Queen Victoria</a> invited him to preach at <a href="Balmoral%20Castle">Balmoral</a>. She had his sermon on Job published.
In 1886, he moved to <a href="Edinburgh">Edinburgh</a>, where he became minister of St. Bernard's Parish Church in <a href="Stockbridge%2C%20Edinburgh">Stockbridge</a> in place of <a href="John%20McMurtrie%20%28moderator%29">Rev John McMurtrie</a>. Here he did his core work as a minister. He lived slightly south at 19 St Bernards Crescent.
In 1879, he declined an invitation to the pastorate of Crown Court, <a href="London">London</a>, in succession to Dr. John Gumming (1807–1881). In 1881 he was chosen as <a href="Baird%20lecturer">Baird lecturer</a>, and took for his subject "Natural Elements of Revealed Theology", and in 1882 he was the St Giles lecturer, his subject being "<a href="Confucianism">Confucianism</a>". In 1890 he was elected a fellow of the <a href="Royal%20Society%20of%20Edinburgh">Royal Society of Edinburgh</a>, the <a href="University%20of%20Aberdeen">University of Aberdeen</a> gave him its honorary <a href="Doctor%20of%20Laws">LL.D.</a>, and in 1899 he was appointed Gifford lecturer by that university, but declined on grounds of health. In the same year he severed his active connection with St. Bernard's.
Published works.
One of his hymns, "O Love That Wilt Not Let Me Go," has passed into the popular hymnology of the <a href="Christianity">Christian</a> Church. Matheson himself wrote of the composition:
"O Love That Wilt Not Let Me Go" was written on the evening of Matheson’s sister’s marriage. Years before, he had been engaged, until his fiancée learned that he was going blind—that there was nothing the doctors could do—and she told him that she could not go through life with a blind man. He went blind while studying for the ministry, and his sister had been the one to care for him through the years. He was now 40, and his sister’s marriage likely brought a fresh reminder of his own heartbreak. It was in the midst of this circumstance that Matheson penned this hymn, which he said was written in five minutes. British composer <a href="Florence%20Margaret%20Spencer%20Palmer">Florence Margaret Spencer Palmer</a> set it to music in 1941.
Matheson published only one volume of verse, "Sacred Songs". All of which he commented 'I simply followed the impression of the moment' His exegesis owes its interest to his subjective resources rather than to breadth of learning; his power lay in spiritual vision rather than balanced judgment, and in the vivid apprehension of the factors which make the Christian personality, rather than in constructive doctrinal statement.
